body:
@pluskid I agree with your idea on softmax should be solely softmax transformation. 
And softmax-loss should be used for loss function. Do you want to take a stab on the refactor?
You need to install R if you are using the R package. If you have installed it and it is not find, try to find it in your system add add path/to/R/bin to the PATH env variable

Yes, currently you need to do it using the symbolic interface. You can bind different part of graph into different devices, and using executor forward/backward to chain them.  
We should add a path in future to support different devices in the same graph in future. Let us know if you are interested
move to #287
@hjk41 I guess we can simply not provide CUDNN and CUDA runtime, and dynamically link to them. Since most CUDA users should have already installed them somewhere in the PATH

The care need to make a truely valid softmax operator, though. Because being able to propback the right gradient for any composition after softmax requires the log-probability instead of probability for numerical stability. A better approach might be take a log-softmax operator to allow arbitrary composition. Or simply restrict softmax to only be able to composed with SoftmaxLoss.

The current decision was made to make things work in a good way for restricted case, which should be changed.
@tqchen We should do refactor soon after we fix RNN stuff, because 2 reason: 1. Capable with CuDNN 2. Better support different loss on Softmax

Hi, all

  Thanks are quite a lot of work need to be done for segmentation task. The multi softmax loss for segmentation is only one issue. However, there are several other ops need to be implemented:
1. The UpSampling layer used in FCN
2. IO part for image segmentation

The most concerned part is the UpSampling layer. It may not easy to implement in current mshadow framework.

@winstywang What do you mean by the IO part? If our softmax is extended to Caffe-like that support evaluating at each pixels, then the whole pipeline is still single-input single-output (though multi-dimensional). It seems the current pipeline fits, or is the current image-records-IO only support single value labels?

@tqchen I agree that combined softmax and logistic loss is much more numerically stable. The compromise in Caffe/Mocha.jl is to provide a `SoftmaxLoss` layer that is essentially combined softmax and logistic loss layer, but do (backward) computation together. It is more efficient _and_ numerically stable. But meanwhile, also offer softmax layer and logistic regression layer separately in case people need to do something else. Actually, a while ago, I was working on a project that use a different loss other than the logistic on the softmax output.

In fact, doing them separately might not be that bad than we think in practice, if you do softmax carefully. I did some experiments quite long time ago (scroll down the [page for the last figure](http://freemind.pluskid.org/machine-learning/softmax-vs-softmax-loss-numerical-stability/)). It seems that the discrepancy is within a reasonable range for relatively bounded inputs even for `Float32`. As far as I know, Theano just [provide softmax and logistic loss separately](http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/library/tensor/nnet/nnet.html), though I do not know if during the compilation stage this actually get optimized into a single `softmax-loss` optimization. If we are still concerned here, the option adopted by Torch might also be possible: they have a `LogSoftmax` layer. :smile:

Fixed by #333 
For auto detect layout, here is the proposed approach in #339 

Add a parameter array.layout(default to auto) to fit and predict. Auto mode will try to detect layout when input is a matrix. If there is ambiguity(square input matrix, which can be rare), ask user to explicitly specify this parameter.

This can benefit potential data science user who are used to put data into a classifier in row major, as read from csv
Thanks! It is cool to use shape inference to do auto selection in prediction time.
In my knowledge, CuDNN doesn't support num_group.  Even in AlexNet2, Alex removed group so feel free to remove group in your network
I'm actually using `num_group` as a feature ;-) I need it in my networks!

I was hoping to find something like:
https://github.com/soumith/cudnn.torch/blob/master/SpatialConvolution.lua#L343

I guess an update to the documentation would be welcomed, since `num_group` doesn't seem to work, even with the CUBLAS backend...

hmm, num_group should work in the original version of CONV as far as I know, but we have to admit that this is a feature that we did not use frequently so maybe we miss something here.

@antinucleon Let us do a round of test with num_group, and maybe configure the operator to return non-cudnn based op when it is bigger than 1

BTW @leehonglak Seems what you want is split channels into groups and do convolution separately. I think you can also achieve it by the following code in current symbolic API, which enables us to use CUDNN as well

``` python
splited = mx.sym.SliceChannel(in, num_outputs=ngroup)
outs = [mx.sym.Convolution(splited.outputs[i], other parameters) for i in range(ngroup)]
final = mx.sym.Concat(*outs)
```
c.f. http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.SliceChannel

Thansk all  for discussion, Learned a lot.
@pluskid Yes, i want to do some experiments with mxnet on segmentation, using [deeplab code](https://bitbucket.org/deeplab/deeplab-public/),  and  [CRF-as-RNN code](https://github.com/torrvision/crfasrnn),   If I have the ability to complete this,  i'll share it ,   but Firstly,  let me be familar with mxnet . ^^
thanks

Currently I use 7.5. Since CUDA runtime can be packaged in our distribution
without any license issue, I just packed it in.

@happynear
updated setupenv.cmd

There is also a related discussion on adding attributes to symbols (#267). One reason is to support this kind of manipulation (e.g. `Readonly` or `Frozen` attribute to some symbols). While there is no specific plan for adding that feature yet. Currently I think what you can do is to hack into `model.py` and manually skip updating the gradients corresponding to the symbols that you want to skip, around here: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L312
You want to add the path to /usr/local/cuda to LD_LIBRARY_PATH on your environment variable

Next PR will contain BlockGradientOp, which can be used to block gradient
backprop

wrote:

It is fairly easy to add these. The first wave of effort was mainly aim to get things done and add things as we need them. Here are the few steps you can do to add these.
- As symbolic function: add them as new operator http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/developer-guide/operator.html  
-  For the cases you discussed, they are actually special case of Activation function template here  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/activation-inl.h
  - The only thing you need to do is define ForwardOp and BackwardOp here, in this file https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/mshadow_op.h

To expose these as NDArray functions, checkout https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray_function.h#L50 square for example, three files are invovled.  
- ndarray_function.h to declare the operator
- ndarray_function-inl.h to declare the unary operator https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray_function-inl.h#L200
- https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray.cc#L652 to register the final one.

We could love your contribution and feedback on this. Things are not the very easiest, but most customization do not involve cuda, but simply write a few lines of expressions and expose them. Hopefully we can improve them over time

hi tq,

thanks !. I assume that if I add it the automatic differentiation works just fine right ?
If you add it as symbolic operator, then auto diff will work out
@tqchen, your solution is even better (i.e. more flexible) for our purpose, thanks a ton!
Unfortunately, it looks like SliceChannel's `num_outputs` is limited to max 5 slices. Is that correct? would it be possible to lift this hard constraint?

It is possible, but I didn't implement it because I a little bit lazy to write more. Also you may consider to slice several times, aka

```
splited = mx.sym.SliceChannel(in, num_outputs=5)
outs = [mx.sym.SliceChannel(splited.outputs[i], num_outputs=5) for i in range(ngroup)]
...
```

to get 25 sliced output
@antinucleon I think we can wrap this behavior, to support arbitrary slice by multiple kernel calls.

I am making a PR to simplify it, now you only need to add one line to expose mshadow functions to ndarray 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/350/files#diff-b200ea3951c4a013796f0e16694abe82R38
Not sure what you mean. Just start to dive into some code today... Now I am able to add exp, log to Activation as you mentioned, but not the ndarray.
Please check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/rnn
Please update mshadow, dmlc-core, ps-lite to newest version too.
I think it was due std::function was not included in default namespace. I will push a fix soon.
seems that it only supports fixed seq_len ? And the compute graph has to ben pre-compiled with fixed sequence length. Is there a suggested solution for variable length model ?

One way to deal with that is unroll to maximum length you want to deal with,  do padding on left over so batching is still enabled.

We can probably enable a condition on the internal nodes to stop execution until the maximum length of current batch
Another way is simply compile a executor for one time-step, and use the imperative API to do the unrolling, this might actually be the easier way, and can be achieved in current API
but in that case, does backprop through time still works ? When we proceed, the gradient will overwrite the gradient for previous step, right?

More specific about previous comment. The problem is when to stop so not waste computation on things that are not needed. What can be done is compile a executor for every time step, say t0, t1, t2, t3.

And use imperative API to chain them up, so the control of stop goes into python side.
We still need a different executor for each time stamp, but use python side to decide when to stop.
does that  mean we need to compile an executor every time? instead of current solution which compiles once
No, compile executor for each time-stamp say t0, t1, t2, and you can reuse t0, t1, t2 next time, but if you need t3, then compile a new one.
@Kublai-Jing Interested in contribute a improved version?
yeah~ need some time to understand the whole mxnet though...

Hope the explanation makes sense to you. There are [documents](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/) explaining things, but be sure to ask if we miss something, or even better contribute to the things so others can benefit from the answer.
This approach can also be generalized a bit, for example, unroll an executor every T step where T is a small number that we might not care about. And use imperative way to chain things up
yes. I might wanna contribute some examples I thought useful for newbie like me. I think that will make people understand whole programming model more quickly
That is awesome

You can add others similarly. You are welcome to open a PR on this

@tqchen 
I assume what you mean is to compile a list of LSTM cell : 
LSTM[i] = LSTM for t_i , 

```
for t in xrange(T):
    LSTM[t] = lstm(...)
    executor[t] = LSTM[t].bind(...)
for t in xrange(len(x_i)):
    input = x_i[t]
    LSTM[t].forward()
for t in reverse(xrange(len(x_i)):
    LSTM[t].backward(...)
update
```

something like this. instead of having one unrolled LSTM with fixed sequence length. This should be more flexible and allow more control from the python side. 

Aside from efficiency, if we use minibatch, what happens if some data already reaches its end of sequence ? If we pad zeros to those data, I believe they will still contribute to the gradient signals, which seems wrong.

Yes,that was what I mean. The padding trick should be ok. As there is already a EOF tag introduced, and we can simply pad future labels to be EOF, and input to be EOF.  The encoder/decoder will catch that EOF follows EOF, and thus no need to depend on previous result, and basically less gradient will be propagated back. This is not perfect solution, but should work
yeah ! we still get wrong gradient, but let the network learns to fix that...lol
Thanks for the contribution! This has now been corrected
Those figures looks a bit blurry on my side. If there is no objection, I might try to re-export those figures and submit a PR to web-data (if I get higher quality images).
That will be awesome

I'm not sure what would be the standard way of dealing with LSTM. But it seems if along with the labels, we provide a stream of `is_end_of_seq` masks. And multiply `1-is_end_of_seq` (maybe with an index shift) with the `prev_hidden_states`. Then it will allow variable-length sequences and automatically reset state propagation over time at the end of the sequence. A minor issue is if the underlying sequence is longer than the un-rolled seq length of the architecture, back-propagate-over-time will get truncated. But I think this won't be a too big issue if we un-roll for a large enough sequence size.
Yes, This is the correct way I think. A harder problem is have the executor to figure out when to stop computation in a transparent way

If the data provider just put each sequence one after another consecutively then it seems there is no need to stop computation. But this is at the cost of higher rate of sequence getting truncated gradients.

not sure I fully understand your question. Here are some answers
- It is definitely possible to do customized data input, you can either use io.NDArrayIter, or simply feed your data into executor, if you are using your own training functions.
- It is possible to backprop the gradient back and get the gradient of arrays, you can do `executor.backward(out_grads=output gradient)`

So what you can likely do is:
- Bind an executor using the set of symbols, to define your computation.
- Do a  executor.forward to get output
- Do some of your EM tricks or other tricks to get the output gradient
- Call executor.backward to prop gradient back, and get the gradient you need
- Do the update you want in python.

In terms of self defined layer. It depends on whether what you need can be readily composed by mxnet's current symbolic API, or if there is more you need. You are always welcomed to open another issue and tell us about your usecase. Thanks!

Great to see your reply! Fast and informative!  Great, with your reply, I think I could start to make progress now, specifically:
1. yes , I would need to customize my data input, so I would feed into an executor
2. great! I would use the "executor.backward" to get the gradients and see the documents in more details
3. For the self defined layer, no, I do not think it could be composed by mxnet's current symbolic API. **Basically, it is not a "layer", just I would use the executor forward result in some other complex function in this "layer", and then use its gradients to combine with executor.backward to complete the chain rule**. Can a python function combine with forward and backward result? **So I see the doc says it could return with NDArray, so I could directly use the forward and backward (gradients) result, right?**
4. If I can get the forward and backward result in one iteration, then E and M step could be done easily, I could **write my own iteration in python rather than fit into mxnet framework** as you mentioned, right? 
5. Thanks a lot. After my implementation, I would be very happy to provide details about the usecase.

I would continue to arise discussions and asked some questions here. I would now check about the document as you suggested. Thanks a lot

Yes, you can directly play with the executor interface and do things you like in NDArray, and training customization and optimization you like. 

There are some modules such as initializer and optimizer which you might be able to re-use, but not required.

You may find this example useful.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/adversary/adversary_generation.ipynb

In this example, there are customized data, layer, loss, backprop, forward etc
Yes you are right! Please submit a PR on this. Thanks!

On the subject of preprocessing, I'm currently getting some sort of memory allocation issue I don't understand when  trying to read my own train/test .rec files:

```
mxnet.base.MXNetError: [21:18:51] src/storage/./cpu_device_storage.h:48: Check failed: (ret) == (0) Allocation failed
```

My train.lst looks like this (all images are 1024x1024x3):

```
0   222 w_7812.jpg
1   44  w_4598.jpg
```

I create the train/test records like so:

```
./bin/im2rec train.lst /home/user/Desktop/train/ train.rec
```

and everything seems to work fine. My iterators are defined as follows:

```
train_dataiter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec="train.rec",
    rand_crop=False,
    rand_mirror=True,
    data_shape=(3,1024,1024),
    batch_size=64,
    preprocess_threads=1)
test_dataiter = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
    path_imgrec="test.rec",
    rand_crop=False,
    rand_mirror=False,
    data_shape=(3,1024,1024),
    batch_size=64,
    preprocess_threads=1)
```

And the remainder is just a truncation of the Cifar10 network example

```
data = mx.symbol.Variable(name="data")
conv1 = ConvFactory(data=data, kernel=(3,3), pad=(1,1), num_filter=96, act_type="relu")
in3a = SimpleFactory(conv1, 32, 32)
in3b = SimpleFactory(in3a, 32, 48)
in3c = DownsampleFactory(in3b, 80)
in4bb =mx.symbol.Dropout(in3c) 
in4c = SimpleFactory(in4bb, 80, 80)
in4cc= mx.symbol.LeakyReLU(in4c)
in4d = SimpleFactory(in4cc, 48, 96)
pool = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=in4cc, pool_type="avg", kernel=(7,7), name="global_pool")
flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool, name="flatten1")
fc = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=447, name="fc1")
softmax = mx.symbol.Softmax(data=fc, name="loss")

gpus=mx.gpu(0)
model=mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=gpus,symbol=softmax,num_round=2,learning_rate=0.05,momentum=.9,wd=0.0001,initializer=mx.init.Uniform(0.07))
model.fit(X=train_dataiter,eval_data=test_dataiter,epoch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(64))
```

3. [Create a new branch with git and manage branches](https://github.com/Kunena/Kunena-Forum/wiki/Create-a-new-branch-with-git-and-manage-branches)

Thanks for your suggestion! We are still designing the general RNN model
API, so we put current LSTM in example folder but not in Python folder.

Please stay tune for a more friendly multi gpu LSTM :)

On Fri, Oct 23, 2015 at 00:46 futurely notifications@github.com wrote:

> In the newly added LSTM examples, the LSTM implementation seems not as
> modular as it could be. The API can be improved to composite more easily
> with other symbols
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/composite_symbol.ipynb.
> 
> Some other popular deep learning libraries with Python API also provided
> LSTM examples with simpler API.
> 
> Keras https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl#newwindow=1&q=keras+lstm
> 
> https://github.com/fchollet/keras/blob/master/examples/lstm_text_generation.py
> 
> model = Sequential()
> model.add(LSTM(512, return_sequences=True, input_shape=(maxlen, len(chars))))
> model.add(Dropout(0.2))
> model.add(LSTM(512, return_sequences=False))
> model.add(Dropout(0.2))
> model.add(Dense(len(chars)))
> model.add(Activation('softmax'))
> 
> https://github.com/fchollet/keras/blob/master/examples/imdb_lstm.py
> 
> model = Sequential()
> model.add(Embedding(max_features, 128, input_length=maxlen))
> model.add(LSTM(128))  # try using a GRU instead, for fun
> model.add(Dropout(0.5))
> model.add(Dense(1))
> model.add(Activation('sigmoid'))
> 
> Lasagne https://www.google.co.in/?gws_rd=ssl#newwindow=1&q=lasagne+lstm
> https://github.com/Lasagne/Lasagne/blob/master/examples/recurrent.py
> 
> ```
> l_in = lasagne.layers.InputLayer(shape=(N_BATCH, MAX_LENGTH, 2))
> l_mask = lasagne.layers.InputLayer(shape=(N_BATCH, MAX_LENGTH))
> l_forward = lasagne.layers.RecurrentLayer(
>     l_in, N_HIDDEN, mask_input=l_mask, grad_clipping=GRAD_CLIP,
>     W_in_to_hid=lasagne.init.HeUniform(),
>     W_hid_to_hid=lasagne.init.HeUniform(),
>     nonlinearity=lasagne.nonlinearities.tanh)
> l_backward = lasagne.layers.RecurrentLayer(
>     l_in, N_HIDDEN, mask_input=l_mask, grad_clipping=GRAD_CLIP,
>     W_in_to_hid=lasagne.init.HeUniform(),
>     W_hid_to_hid=lasagne.init.HeUniform(),
>     nonlinearity=lasagne.nonlinearities.tanh, backwards=True)
> l_forward_slice = lasagne.layers.SliceLayer(l_forward, -1, 1)
> l_backward_slice = lasagne.layers.SliceLayer(l_backward, 0, 1)
> l_sum = lasagne.layers.ConcatLayer([l_forward_slice, l_backward_slice])
> l_out = lasagne.layers.DenseLayer(
>     l_sum, num_units=1, nonlinearity=lasagne.nonlinearities.tanh)
> ```
> 
> Neon https://www.google.co.in/?gws_rd=ssl#newwindow=1&q=neon+lstm
> https://github.com/NervanaSystems/neon/blob/master/examples/imdb_lstm.py
> 
> layers = [
>     LookupTable(vocab_size=vocab_size, embedding_dim=embedding_dim, init=init_emb),
>     LSTM(hidden_size, init_glorot, activation=Tanh(),
>          gate_activation=Logistic(), reset_cells=True),
>     RecurrentSum(),
>     Dropout(keep=0.5),
>     Affine(2, init_glorot, bias=init_glorot, activation=Softmax())
> ]
> 
> https://github.com/NervanaSystems/neon/blob/master/examples/word_lstm.py
> 
> if rlayer_type == 'lstm':
>     rlayer1 = LSTM(hidden_size, init, Logistic(), Tanh())
>     rlayer2 = LSTM(hidden_size, init, Logistic(), Tanh())elif rlayer_type == 'gru':
>     rlayer1 = GRU(hidden_size, init, activation=Tanh(), gate_activation=Logistic())
>     rlayer2 = GRU(hidden_size, init, activation=Tanh(), gate_activation=Logistic())else:
>     raise NotImplementedError('%s layer not implemented' % rlayer_type)
> 
> layers = [
>     rlayer1,
>     rlayer2,
>     Affine(len(train_set.vocab), init, bias=init, activation=Softmax())
> ]
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/376.

Thanks for advice! It's very valuable and informative.

We will move the pretrained model from [notebook](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/notebooks/predict-with-pretrained-model.ipynb) to some kind of model zoo this week. What's more, we will release a model trained on 21k classes.

Thanks again! We have some benchmarks but are straightly compared to dmlc/cxxnet. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/imagenet

As cxxnet is a highly optimized library, you may already know the result.

We won't aim to make a speed war between each tools, instead we want to learn from each other, that's why we released all "secret" design documents. But as you suggested, we will consider a friendly way to make a benchmark.

if not set USE_BLAS correctly, it may build successfully, but can't  import  mxnet. so:
1. make sure that in your config.mk, the set is : USE_BLAS = atlas
2. make sure that libatlas.so is in your environment 
3. make clean && make -j4 ; cd python ; python setup.py install --prefix /home/myhome/local
@futurely Thanks for the helpful suggestions.  If you have ideas on how things can be done, you are more than welcomed to contribute your wisdom to the project :)
You can feed the model parameters into a new FeedforwardModel https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/model.py#L492 and call fit again.
That is great. Thanks for the contribution. I am closing this due to #372

Hmm, this could due to the allocation of too large memory chunk being requested. Can you check what was the size being requested on your side https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/storage/cpu_device_storage.h#L47

Another two questions:
1. **Loss for regression**: I figured out that there are sigmoid output and linear output. Are they used for regression (Euclidean loss)? Can I set multi-dimensional real-valued labels for data points?
2. **Multi-loss**: I want to have several different losses for one network, e.g. k outputs for classification with softmax loss and m outputs for regression with Euclidean loss. How can I achieve this?

I am more than pleased to be able to make some contributions.

Sure, I was waiting for you to close this issue :-)

- Yes, you can feed multi dimensional real value labels in.
- Multi-loss: We haven't roll this out in the Feedforward API, mainly due to the first wave change to bring the API ready for the easiest task, but only minor changes are needed to be make to model training code to achieve this (mainly for copying the labels to right position).
  - also see the rnn example, which contains multiple loss
  - Please open a issue on this, or even better consider contributing:)
I can check when I get home; is the output of posix_memalign produced at some point in the run?  I'm not entirely clear on how to check the size of the request.

You can change this line https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/storage/cpu_device_storage.h#L48 to

```
  CHECK_EQ(ret, 0) << "Allocation failed, " << "requested size = "<< size;
```
Thanks for pointing this out, can you open a PR on this? The source is here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/developer-guide/note_memory.md
